text: Promotes or demotes attributes from one geometry level to another.

This node provides a straightforward way to convert an attribute
from one class to another. For example, a point attribute can be
converted to a primitive attribute using any one of a number of
different merge methods.
For index attributes, the merge methods treat the attribute as a string -

will perform concatenation, and the other
numeric methods will resort to

For attributes with multiple components (such as vectors), each merge is
done independently on each component.
Use Attribute Promote when you want to copy attributes between geometry in the same stream (it has one input). Use
when you want to copy attributes from geometry in one input onto geometry in another input.
The name of the attribute in the source class. For example,

will pick color. This can also be a pattern or space-separated list of
    attributes, such as

The class that the attribute starts in. It can be one
    of point, primitive, detail, or vertex.

The class to which the attribute is promoted.
    Unless
. Otherwise a warning is raised and nothing is done.
The name of a partition attribute in the

, which must be a string or integer type.
    Each point/vertex/primitive where the attribute has the same value is considered part of the same piece.
    The
will be applied using the corresponding elements in the
for the piece, and the result will be written to all of the piece’s elements.
For example, when promoting from points to primitives, the
will be applied to all of the points referenced by the primitives in the piece:
will not be included multiple times (for example, if a point is referenced by multiple primitives in the piece).
will be ordered by index (for example,
will return the value for the lowest point index of any point referenced by the piece’s primitives).
may be the same as the
when using a piece attribute (for example, this can be used to compute the average value of an attribute for each piece).

Whenever there is more than one attribute in the original class
    that matches a single entity in the new class, some method must
    be used to determine the new value. For example, if converting
    from point attribute to primitive attribute, there will be many
    points corresponding to a single polygon.

The mean, or the sum of all matches divided by the number of
        matches.

The most common match. If there is more than one most
        common, it will be the minimum of the most common.

The middle of the matches. If there is an even number of
        elements, it is the higher of the two possible middles.
All of the matches added together.
All of the matches squared, and then added together.

The square root of the average of the squares of all the
        matches.

The first valid match. For promoting points to primitives,
        this would be the point of the first vertex in the
        primitive.

The last valid match. For promoting points to primitives,
        this would be the point of the last vertex in the
        primitive.

Provided the source attribute is a tuple attribute, a new
        array attribute is created. The array attribute is populated
        with all the values of the matches.

When turned off, the new attribute name will match the original
    name.
The new name for the attribute if

is turned on.
    If the source is a pattern, this new name should be a pattern that can
    expand to the same length.  Glob-style renaming is done, so if the
    matching pattern is

When turned on, the original attribute is deleted after promotion. Note that in some cases, such as promoting a vertex attribute to a point attribute of the same name, the original attribute will always be deleted. To avoid this, rename the attribute when promoting.

title: Attribute Promote
summary: Promotes or demotes attributes from one geometry level to another.
